1.text: Better a dry morsel in quietness than a house full of feasting with strife.

2.text: A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son and share his inheritance as one of the brothers.

3.text: A crucible for silver and a furnace for gold, but the LORD is the tester of hearts.

4.text: A wicked man listens to evil lips; a liar gives ear to a destructive tongue.

5.text: He who mocks the poor insults their Maker; whoever gloats over calamity will not go unpunished.

6.text: Grandchildren are the crown of the aged, and the glory of a son is his father.

7.text: Eloquent words are unfit for a fool; how much worse are lying lips to a ruler!

8.text: A bribe is a charm to its giver; wherever he turns, he succeeds.

9.text: Whoever conceals an offense promotes love, but he who brings it up separates friends.

10.text: A rebuke cuts into a man of discernment deeper than a hundred lashes cut into a fool.

11.text: An evil man seeks only rebellion; a cruel messenger will be sent against him.

12.text: It is better to meet a bear robbed of her cubs than a fool in his folly.

13.text: If anyone returns evil for good, evil will never leave his house.

14.text: To start a quarrel is to release a flood; so abandon the dispute before it breaks out.

15.text: Acquitting the guilty and condemning the righteousâ€”both are detestable to the LORD.

16.text: Why should the fool have money in his hand with no intention of buying wisdom?

17.text: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.

18.text: A man lacking judgment strikes hands in pledge and puts up security for his neighbor.

19.text: He who loves transgression loves strife; he who builds his gate high invites destruction.

20.text: The one with a perverse heart finds no good, and he whose tongue is deceitful falls into trouble.

21.text: A man fathers a fool to his own grief; the father of a fool has no joy.

22.text: A joyful heart is good medicine, but a broken spirit dries up the bones.

23.text: A wicked man takes a covert bribe to subvert the course of justice.

24.text: Wisdom is the focus of the discerning, but the eyes of a fool wander to the ends of the earth.

25.text: A foolish son brings grief to his father and bitterness to her who bore him.

26.text: It is surely not good to punish the innocent or to flog a noble for his honesty.

27.text: A man of knowledge restrains his words, and a man of understanding maintains a calm spirit.

28.text: Even a fool is considered wise if he keeps silent, and discerning when he holds his tongue.
